title: 115_s1777
content: The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes an excise tax on corporations with low-wage employees under a new chapter in the Internal Revenue Code. The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes a tax on applicable employers with low-wage employees based on the aggregate amount of wages paid during the calendar year. The term "applicable employer" refers to any employer who was required to make tax deposits under specific chapters for more than 180 days in the preceding year. The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes a tax on applicable employers with low-wage employees based on the aggregate amount of wages paid during the calendar year. The term "applicable employer" excludes Federal or governmental entities, churches, or qualified church organizations. Aggregation rules from section 414 apply, with a substitution of 'more than 50 percent' for 'more than 80 percent'. The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes a tax on applicable employers with low-wage employees. The term "applicable employer" excludes Federal or governmental entities, churches, or qualified church organizations. For subsections (b) and (c) of the Act, 'more than 50 percent' replaces 'more than 80 percent'. A low-wage employee is defined as someone earning less than 218 percent of the Federal poverty line. The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes a tax on applicable employers with low-wage employees. The amount described in subparagraph (A) is reduced for employees employed for less than the entire year. The applicable percentage is determined for subsection (a) based on the number of weeks the individual was not an employee of the applicable employer. The applicable employee ratio determines the percentage for applicable employers with low-wage employees: 25% for 25% or less, 50% for greater than 25% but not greater than 50%, 75% for greater than 50% but not greater than 75%, and 100% for greater than 75%. The low-wage employee ratio is calculated as the percentage of low-wage employees to total employees for an applicable employer. A health and retirement offset reduces the applicable percentage by 25 points for qualifying employers. An applicable employer's applicable percentage is reduced by 25 percentage points if they meet certain requirements, including offering minimum essential coverage to all full-time low-wage employees and their families under an eligible employer-sponsored health plan. The text chunk discusses the requirements for an eligible employer-sponsored health plan, including the plan's share of allowed costs, the employee's required contribution, and meeting retirement plan requirements for low-wage employees. The text chunk outlines the retirement plan requirements for low-wage employees, stating that the applicable employer must meet certain criteria for employees to be eligible to participate in eligible retirement plans. The text outlines eligibility criteria for employees to participate in eligible retirement plans maintained by the applicable employer, requiring a defined contribution plan with minimum employer contributions or a defined benefit plan with specific employee benefits. The text specifies that a defined benefit plan must provide an annual retirement benefit not less than 2 percent multiplied by the employee's years of service with the employer or 20 percent multiplied by the employee's final average pay. The defined benefit plan must provide an annual retirement benefit not less than 2 percent multiplied by the employee's years of service with the employer or 20 percent multiplied by the employee's final average pay. Additionally, the plan must meet certain interest credit and pay credit requirements for the employee. The defined benefit plan must provide an annual retirement benefit not less than 2 percent multiplied by the employee's years of service with the employer or 20 percent multiplied by the employee's final average pay. The employee receives a pay credit for the plan year which is not less than 5 percent of compensation. Definitions and special rules apply for eligible retirement plans and final average pay calculations. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for an employer to meet retirement plan requirements through a combination of defined contribution or defined benefit plans. Plans must meet requirements without considering social security contributions and benefits. Plans must meet requirements without taking into account social security and similar contributions and benefits. Certain employees may be excluded based on age and years of service. Certain employees may be excluded from the plan if they have less than 1 year of service, are covered under a collective bargaining agreement, or are nonresident aliens working outside the United States. The text discusses the exclusion of certain employees from a plan based on criteria such as less than 1 year of service, coverage under a collective bargaining agreement, or being nonresident aliens working outside the United States. It also includes definitions of terms like 'wages' and rules for tax allocation among entities treated as a single employer. Chapter 37--Corporate Responsibility Tax. The amendments made by this section apply to calendar years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act.
